abstract.p: Howard Goldberg reviews A et P de Villaine's 1998 aligote white wine from Bouzeron; photo (M)

block.p: Mention aligote to a sommelier in Lyon and, pouf, a kir materializes. But ladling cassis into A. et P. de Villaine's '98 aligote would be a gastronomic offense. It would drown the honeyed bouquet and purity of flavor in this strikingly crisp white from Bouzeron, a Cote Chalonnaise village that specializes in aligote.

Although aligote is a second-class Burgundian grape, under the stewardship of Aubert de Villaine, who is also a part owner of Domaine de la Romanee-Conti -- a national treasure whose wines sell for hundreds of dollars -- it can reach near parity with chardonnay.

Although aligote is a second-class Burgundian grape, under the stewardship of Aubert de Villaine, who is also a part owner of Domaine de la Romanee-Conti -- a national treasure whose wines sell for hundreds of dollars -- it can reach near parity with chardonnay.
The caressing, earthy '98, an impeccably made aperitif, is available at a mere $14 at the Burgundy Wine Company, 323 West 11th Street (Greenwich Street), in Manhattan.

A Chablis, the '98 Domaine Barat ($13) -- delicately honeyed, mouth-filling, flinty -- is the aligote's soul mate and an equally fit companion for oysters. To savor the Barat properly, sip it in small drafts at a snail's pace.

Beaumes-de-Venise, in the southern Cotes-du-Rhone, tends to be identified only with a light fruity muscat dessert wine that's everyone's Lolita. But reds, less often seen, originate in the appellation, too, and the Burgundy Wine Company offers a plush, juicy one.

At first, the '97 Cuvee Saint-Martin from Domaine de la Ferme Saint-Martin ($12) seems to be only a cool-weather red. But poured into glasses half an hour before guests arrive for a grilled-meat dinner, it becomes peppery, spicy and raisiny, with a whiff of roasted nuts, and turns into a great slosh with the fatty entree.
